headline: First aliyah
text: The First Aliyah, occurring between 1882 and 1903, marked the beginning of significant Jewish immigration to Palestine, then part of the Ottoman Empire. Prompted by persecution and pogroms in Eastern Europe and inspired by Zionist ideals (the belief that Jews have a right to an indenpendent state in the land of Israel/Palestine), approximately 25,000-35,000 Jews, mainly from Russia and Romania, settled in the region. They established agricultural communities and laid the foundations for the modern Jewish state, despite facing numerous challenges such as harsh conditions, diseases, and economic hardships. This wave of immigration played a crucial role in the early development of the Jewish presence in Palestine.
mediaCredit: The Palmach Archive via the PikiWiki - Israel free image collection project
mediaCaption: Jews waiting to make aliyah to Israel

headline: 5th aliyah due to Nazi persecution
text: The first large-scale influx of Jews occurred due to Nazi persecution during British mandate in 1930.
mediaCaption: Immigrants from Germany arriving at the port of Jaffa in 1933

headline: Division of the two states: an Arab state and a Jewish state. (UN partition plan: Resolution 181 voted by the UN General Assembly)
text: The Jewish community in Palestine started growing, and it led to increased conflict between Palestinians who wanted self rule and Jews who believed they also had a right to the region. In this context, Britain joined the United Nations in 1947 and issued Resolution 181. This resolution divided the region into two states: an Arab state and a Jewish state. Which the Jews accepted while the Arabs rejected it
mediaCaption: UN proposed partition plan

headline: Israel wins the Independence war
text: In 1948, after the Arabs rejected the partition plan, they launched a war against the Jews. The Jews won this war, and proclaimed the independent state of Israel for the first time, with 77 per cent of the territory of mandatory Palestine, including western Jerusalem. The Palestinians call this event "Nakba" which translates to the catastrophe. 700k Palestinians were displaced from Israel proper
mediaCaption: Israeli soldiers raise the flag to mark the end of the war

headline: Jewish exodus from the Muslim world
text: In the aftermath of the 1948 war, other Muslim countries expelled their Jews as retaliation for the expulsion of the Palestinians. Approximately 650k Jews migrated, fled, or were expelled from Muslim-majority countries throughout Africa and Asia
mediaCaption: Jewish Yemenite family walking through the desert to a reception camp

headline: Absent Property Act 1950
text: This law codifies the right for Jews, and only Jews to claim land and property owned by them, before the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948. Other groups who owned land do not have this right
mediaCaption: Palestinian Refugees

headline: Israel takes all Gaza
text: In 1967, after the Six-Day War, Israel gained control of all of Gaza and the West Bank, and also the Sinai penninsula, leading to a new exodus of 280,000 to 325,000 Palestinians. This war marks the official beginning of the occupation of these 2 territories, which are collectively known as Palestine. In the immediate aftermath of this war, Israel started pursuing an explicit settlement policy of bringning in Jews into these 2 territories, particularly the more sparely populated West Bank
mediaCaption: Territorial changes after the war

headline: Yom Kippur War
text: The Yom Kippur War, fought in October 1973, was a conflict between Israel and a coalition of Arab states led by Egypt and Syria. The war began on Yom Kippur, the holiest day in Judaism, with a surprise attack by the Arab coalition. Despite initial setbacks, Israel managed to regroup and launch counteroffensives, eventually regaining lost territories. The war resulted in significant casualties on both sides and had lasting geopolitical effects. It led to increased U.S. and Soviet involvement in the region, ultimately paving the way for subsequent peace negotiations, including the Camp David Accords between Israel and Egypt.

headline: Egypt and Israel make peace, Sinai returned
text: The peace between Israel and Egypt, marked by the Camp David Accords in 1978 and the Egypt-Israel Peace Treaty in 1979, ended decades of conflict between the two nations. As part of the agreement, Israel returned the Sinai Peninsula to Egypt, which it had occupied since the Six-Day War in 1967. This historic treaty established diplomatic relations and mutual recognition, significantly reducing regional tensions and setting a precedent for future Arab-Israeli peace efforts.
mediaCaption: Sadat, Carter and Begin at the signing ceremony

headline: Jerusalem law
text: After annexing East Jerusalem, Israel decided this year to officially make Jerusalem it's capital, previously being Tel Aviv
mediaCaption: Jerusalem

headline: First Intifada and the birth of Hamas
text: The First Intifada, spanning from 1987 to 1993, was a Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Triggered by an incident involving an Israeli military vehicle that killed four Palestinians, the uprising involved widespread protests, civil disobedience, and violent clashes. The unrest led to significant casualties and drew international attention to the Palestinian cause. It also prompted a shift in Israeli-Palestinian relations, culminating in the 1993 Oslo Accords, which aimed to establish a framework for peace and the eventual creation of a Palestinian state.
mediaCaption: Barricades during the Intifada

headline: Oslo accords
text: The Oslo Accords, signed in 1993, were a series of agreements between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) aimed at resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The accords established mutual recognition between Israel and the PLO and outlined a framework for Palestinian self-governance in parts of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, setting the stage for further negotiations on critical issues like borders, refugees, and Jerusalem. Despite initial optimism, the accords faced numerous challenges and did not lead to a final peace agreement.
mediaCaption: Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, U.S. president Bill Clinton, and PLO chairman Yasser Arafat.

headline: Camp David summit failure
text: After the Oslo accords the 2000 Camp David Summit was held in July 2000 at Camp David, Maryland, aimed at resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Hosted by U.S. President Bill Clinton, the summit brought together Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian Authority Chairman Yasser Arafat. The negotiations focused on core issues, including borders, the status of Jerusalem, Palestinian refugees, and security arrangements. Despite intense discussions, the summit ended without an agreement, as significant gaps remained on critical issues. The failure of the summit is often cited as a key moment leading to the outbreak of the Second Intifada later that year.
mediaCaption: President Clinton walks with Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Yasser Arafat of the Palestinian Authority on the grounds of Camp David

headline: Second Intifada
text: The Second Intifada, also known as the Al-Aqsa Intifada, was a period of intensified Israeli-Palestinian violence that began in late September 2000 and lasted until around 2005. Triggered by Ariel Sharon's visit to the Temple Mount, and the failure of Camp David, the conflict involved frequent clashes, suicide bombings, and military operations, resulting in significant casualties on both sides. In the aftermath, Israel began constructing the West Bank barrier, citing security concerns, while Palestinians viewed it as a land grab. The violence deepened mistrust and animosity, severely impacting the peace process and further entrenching divisions between Israelis and Palestinians.
mediaCaption: The aftermath of a bus bombing in Haifa in 2003

headline: Israel pulls out of Gaza
text: In 2005, Israel withdrew from the Gaza Strip and dismantled its settlements. Israel also withdrew from the Philadelphi Route, a narrow strip of land adjacent to the border with Egypt, after Egypt agreed to secure its side of the border after the Agreement on Movement and Access, known as the Rafah Agreement. The Gaza Strip was left under the control of the Palestinian Authority
mediaCaption: A group of residents refuses to evacuate the Israeli settlement Bedolach

headline: Gaza taken over by Hamas
text: In the Palestinian parliamentary elections held on 25 January 2006, Hamas won 74 out of 132 total seats (56%). When Hamas assumed power the next month, Israel, the United States, the EU, Russia and the UN demanded that Hamas accept all previous agreements, recognize Israel's right to exist, and renounce violence. Hamas refused Shortly after, Hamas took control of the Gaza Strip in the course of the Battle of Gaza (June 2007), seizing government institutions and replacing Fatah and other government officials with its own.
mediaCaption: Palestinian supporters of Hamas gather for a pre-election rally in the West Bank town of Ramallah

headline: Military offensive on Gaza Strip
text: On December 27, 2008, Israel launched a vast air offensive against the Gaza Strip to put an end to constant barrages of rocket fire by hamas (Operation Cast Lead). On January 18, 2009, a ceasefire put an end to the operation. Some 1,400 Palestinians and 13 Israelis were killed.
mediaCaption: Weapons found in a mosque during Operation Cast Lead

headline: UN partially recognizes Palestine
text: In 2012, the United Nations General Assembly granted Palestine non-member observer state status, a symbolic recognition of Palestinian statehood that highlighted ongoing international support for a two-state solution.
mediaCaption: UN delegates applaud after United Nations General Assembly resolution 67/19 is passed

headline: US recognizes Jerusalem as capital of Israel
mediaCaption: Dedication ceremony in Jerusalem, Israel

headline: The Great March of Return
text: In 2018, the Great March of Return takes place. There were a some protest about the Gaza Strip, claiming the right to return of the displaced persons and their descendants of the 1948 war to what is today Israel. The protests ended being deadly, with 223 Palestinians being killed.
mediaCaption: Near Gaza's border with Israel in 2018

headline: Hamas launches a deadly attack on Israel
text: Hamas chooses the Jewish lholiday of Simchat Torah to launch the deadliest attack on Jews since the Holocaust. First, the group fires a barrage of rockets towards Israeli cities. Then, fighters break  through the border fence and use paragliders and speedboats to attack Israel by land, air and sea. Israeli officials say around 1,200 people are killed and more than 250 people are kidnapped and taken to Gaza. The next day, Israel declares war.
mediaCaption: Rockets are fired toward Israel from the Gaza Strip on Saturday.

headline: Israel oders "Complete Siege" of Gaza
text: The enclave, home to more than 2 million Palestinians, has already been under blockade for 16 years. Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant says "no electricity, no food, no fuel" will be allowed to enter.
mediaCaption: Smoke rises after Israeli air strikes near the border east of Rafah city in the southern Gaza Strip, Oct. 8, 2023.

headline: Israel warns people to evacuate northern Gaza
text: Israel gives the more than 1 million people who live in northern Gaza 24 hours to evacuate southward. Hundreds of thousand heed the warning. Others refuse to leave.
mediaCredit: Mahmud Hams / AFP Via Getty Images
mediaCaption: Palestinians with their belongings flee from their homes following Israeli airstrikes in Gaza City on Friday.

headline: At least 100 people killed in a blast at Al-Ahli Hospital
text: At least 100 people are killed when an explosion hits Al-Ahli Hospital in Gaza City. hamas blames an Israeli strike. Israel blames a stray rocket launched by Palestinian militants.
mediaCaption: Al-Ahli Baptist Hospital in Gaza after the explosion

headline: Israel launches ground invasion
text: The Israeli military expands its ground operations despite warnings from the Biden Administration that a full-scale assault could cause heavy civilian casualties.
mediaCaption: Israeli army infantry fighting vehicles (IFVs) deploy along the border with the Gaza Strip in southern Israel. The Israeli military says its troops, backed by tanks, carried out raids inside the Gaza Strip on Friday

headline: Israeli strikes on Jabalya kill more than 100 people
text: Israel strikes on the Jabalya refugee camp in northern Gaza kill more than 110 people and wound hundreds more. Israel's military says it killed a senior Hamas commander and other militants. The U.N. human rights office expresses "serious concerns that these are disproportionate attacks that could amount to war crimes."
mediaCaption: Hundreds of people were seen searching the wreckage for the dead and injured

headline: Israeli forces raid Al-Shifa Hospital
text: The Israeli Defense Forces raid Al-Shifa Hospital, which houses hundreds of patients and thousands of displaced people. Intense fighting in the area means the hospital has been effectively sealed off that month. Patients including premature babies die when the hospital loses electricity. Israel surrounds and raids other hospitals in the months that follow. In February, the U.N. human rights office accuses Israel of "a pattern of attacks" against hospitals. The IDF accuses Hamas of "cynically using hospitals for terror."

headline: Israel-Hamas pause fighting in hostages-for-prisoners deal
text: Israel and Hamas agree to pause fighting and exchange some of the hostages for prisoners, and allow more aid into Gaza. Hamas releases more than 100 Israeli hostages. Israel releases 240 Palestinian held as prisoners. Freed hostages begin sharing accounts of  their time in captivity.The pause ends after seven days, each side says the other breached the deal.
mediaCaption: People react in Tel Aviv as they hear the news of the release of 13 Israeli hostages held by Hamas in Gaza.(Ariel Schalit/The Associated Press)

headline: Israeli forces mistakenly kill three hostages
text: The IDF announces that its forces have mistakenly shot dead tthree Israeli hostages in Gaza City. The three men were shirtless and brandishing a makeshift white flag as they approached an IDF position.
mediaCaption: (From L-R) Hostages Yotam Haim, Samar Talalka and Alon Lulu Shamriz, who were killed mistakenly by IDF troops in Gaza on December 15, 2023. (Courtesy)

headline: South Africa presents genocide case against Israel before U.N. court
text: South Africa argues before the International Court of Justice that Israel has committed genocidal acts in Gaza, a claim Israel and the U.S. deny. A ruling on genocide could take years.
mediaCredit: (Photo by Selman Aksunger/Anadolu via Getty Images)
mediaCaption: Thursday, January 11, marked the start of an unprecedented legal confrontation at the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in The Hague in the Netherlands, as South Africa argued that Israel’s actions in Gaza amount to “genocide”.

headline: 21 Israeli soldiers killed while trying to build Gaza buffer
text: Two-dozen troops are killed in the bloodiest day for the Israeli military since the start of the war. Twenty-one are killed while trying to demolish two buildings, leading Israel to confirm it is building a buffer zone in Gaza to further separate the enclave from Israel.
mediaCaption: Soldiers killed in the central Gaza Strip on January 22, 2024: Top (L-R): Sgt. Maj. (res.) Mark Kononovich, Sgt. First Class (res.) Israel Socol, Sgt. Maj. (res.) Adam Bismut, Sgt. Maj. (res.) Shay Biton Hayun, Sgt. Maj. (res.) Itamar Tal, Sgt. Maj. (res.) Daniel Kasau Zegeye, Sgt. First Class (res.) Cedrick Garin; middle: Sgt. First Class (res.) Hadar Kapeluk, Sgt. Maj. (res.) Matan Lazar, Cpt. (res.) Ariel Mordechay Wollfstal, Master Sgt. (res.), Elkana Vizel, Cpt. (res.) Nir Binyamin, Sgt. First Class (res.) Sagi Idan, Sgt. First Class (res.) Ahmad Abu Latif; bottom: Sgt. Maj. (res.) Rafael Elias Mosheyoff, Sgt. First Class (res.) Nicholas Berger, Master Sgt. (res.) Yoav Levi, Sgt. First Class (res.) Yuval Lopez, Sgt. First Class (res.) Elkana Yehuda Sfez, Sgt. Maj. (res.) Sergey Gontmaher, Sgt. Maj. (res.) Barak Haim Ben Valid. (Israel Defense Forces, courtesy; combo image: Times of Israel)

headline: Netanyahu outlines hard-line vision for postwar Gaza
text: After months of pressure, Netanyahu's office releases his postway plans for Gaza. He says Israel will maintain indefinite military control of Gaza and assume greater control of its southern border, but leaves open the possibility of palestinian Authority officials playing a role.
mediaCaption: Under Mr Netanyahu's plan, Palestinians with no links to armed groups would run Gaza

headline: Death toll passes 30,000
text: Casualties each over 30,000 killed and 70,000 wounded, according to the Gaza Health Ministry. That means around 1 in 20 in Gaza are dead or wounded.
mediaCaption: The majority of those killed are thought to be women and children

headline: Donors deliver aid by air and sea
text: Humanitarian groups warn famine is imminent, and aid routes become deadly flash points. In one incident more that 100 people are killed, when thousands converge on aid convoy and Israeli troops open fire. The U.S. begins dropping food into Gaza by airplane. A humanitarian ship run by chef José Andrés' Washington-based World Central Kitchen and the search-and-rescue group Open Arms make the first delivery to Gaza by sea.
mediaCaption: The Israeli military released aerial video showing hundreds of Palestinians crowding round aid lorries

headline: Israel strikes kill 7 World Central Kitchen workers
text: Israeli airstrikes kill seven World Central Kitchen workers delivering aid in Gaza. The team had clearance from the Israeli military. Following military investigation, Israel says the strikes on the aid convoy violated military procedures and were a "grave mistake." World Central Kitchen calls for an independent investigation.
mediaCaption: People inspect the site where World Central Kitchen workers were killed in Deir Al-Balah, Gaza Strip, Tuesday, April 2, 2024.  ABDEL KAREEM HANA/AP
